candidates.name: Shaun Curtis
candidates.why_elect: Good governance enables our valued DHB staff to care for our communities effectively. I can bring the requisite skills and experience to deliver this, along with some fresh thinking. Everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect, and I will ensure people are forefront in my thoughts and actions.
candidates.why_stand: I'm standing for the future of our healthcare—I believe fresh and vibrant thinking will be a welcome addition in the boardroom. I am passionate about ensuring the quality of life for all Northlanders, and our health is crucial to this.

candidates.name: Kyle Eggleton
candidates.why_elect: I am a seventh generation Northlander and have worked as a rural general practitioner in Northland for 16 year. I sit on numerous international, national and local health governance committees. In addition I am a Senior Lecturer at the University of Auckland and research quality health care.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about ensuring that people can get the health care that they need and deserve. Unfortunately Northland has some of the worse health statistics in NZ despite living in one of the best places in NZ. All Northlanders are therefore entitled to the very best health care.

candidates.name: Libby Jones
candidates.why_elect: For 30 years I have worked in health and social services in clinical, leadership and funding roles. Currently I am the Manager of Jigsaw North Family Services assisting children and families in Whangarei. I have 18 years governance experience across health, education, social services, rural and local government.
candidates.why_stand: As a current director on NDHB I know that while we are seeing positive health improvements, it is not enough and we need to keep our focus on prevention of ill health, working together more effectively and timely access to quality health services for all.

candidates.name: Sally Macauley
candidates.why_elect: I have been an elected member for the last 18 years with a three year chairmanship of NDHB Community, Public Health and Disabilities and 6 years Deputy Chairman. I have a commerce and finance background. I foremost believe the health and safety of our workforce being imperative.
candidates.why_stand: As Chairman for the last 3 years I've lead a team that has successfully governed and overseen the health and welfare of Northland within available resources. It is imperative we effectively engage with the local Māori Stakeholders.

candidates.name: Carol Peters
candidates.why_elect: I'm a flax-roots community development worker who supports people to lift the wellbeing of their own communities. I participated in setting up a community health centre, community law, and housing projects. I am experienced at listening to people's problems, so will advocate for our health system to be more responsive.
candidates.why_stand: From my work, I see the very serious health requirements some local people have, especially when they are ageing, have poor housing, cannot afford good food. I wish to promote joined-up health services that address the causes of poor health, with resources and appropriate staff to meet these needs.

candidates.name: John Bain
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in Northland for 46 years and have been involved with several charities most of which I have Chaired in part. The most publicly visible is the building of world class and envied patient retrieval system both on road and helicopter. I am a manager who gets things done.
candidates.why_stand: I am a current Board member and have knowledge from Ambulance and Helicopter background that serves me well on the DHB. We are in a time of change with treatments and science and I feel I can contribute to this world to the advantage of all Northlanders.

candidates.name: Bill Bradford
candidates.why_elect: I have spent many years managing not for profit GP and dental services and a PHO providing services for low income people. I have also worked in public health. I believe elected DHB members have a duty to ensure the voice of local communities is heard at all political levels.
candidates.why_stand: I have always loved Northland but have never been able to accept the levels of poverty, disadvantage and exclusion that are part of the lives of too many residents. Quality primary health care and bold public health initiatives can make a difference. We can do a lot better.

candidates.name: John Vujcich
candidates.why_elect: I'm a strategic and critical thinker with a strong background in science and technology and have governance and business experience. I'm born in the Hokianga, understand the culture and challenges we face and have the desire to improve general health statistics of all our people. I represent rural/urban Northland.
candidates.why_stand: I want to see everyone, especially our rural people, have improved access to good quality local health services. I'm offended by the poor health statistics and believe improved wellbeing can be achieved by all organisations across all sectors taking into account the health implications of their decisions.

candidates.name: Harko Brown
candidates.why_elect: I have worked long and hard with many other people and organisations in Northland, especially around youth mental health initiatives, to uplift and upskill our future generations so I am not a 'come-lately', I always have my sleeves rolled-up. I am a specialist educator with masters, honours and conjoint degrees.
candidates.why_stand: I have skills and networks which can benefit the health provision of Northlanders. Mental health issues are huge and we need to address those with cultural understandings which I can help to facilitate. We have a beautiful region and amazing people—let's work for the best health options.

candidates.name: Sophia Xiao-Colley
candidates.why_elect: My life journey has had a lot of ups and downs, and there have been some useful lessons for me. My motto is: love yourself, do your best, enjoy life as a learning journey, master the art of balance.
candidates.why_stand: I am thankful for the support I have received as a refugee from China. My husband and our 6-year-old daughter are supporting me to pay back our community. I genuinely believe that there is healing power within the human body's ecosystem.

candidates.name: Jeffrey Burson
candidates.why_elect: I have the financial skills to help achieve the above. In addition I have friends and family that work with the DHB across all levels to feed back and ensure what we are doing at board level is making a difference.
candidates.why_stand: Our front line staff throughout Northland do an amazing job with the resources they have available. I want to provide sound governance to the organisation so these staff can continue their work, ideally with additional resources.

candidates.name: Steve Capper
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in Whangarei for all but 2 years of my life. I have a wealth of business knowledge from running my own business and being a senior manager in one of Whangarei's largest manufacturers. I have a community focused awareness and want to help our community thrive.
candidates.why_stand: Northland Is a fantastic place to live, and we need to ensure we are providing the services required by our aging and growing population. We are to heavily reliant on specialist service support from regions outside of Northland. I wish to improve this and increase funding for us all.

candidates.name: Vince Cocurullo
candidates.why_elect: As a WDC Councillor, I believe in strong governance and management. I listen, and deal with issues as they happen, however I also believe in getting people to help themselves. As a business person, I believe in making sure my clients are looked after, the NDHB should be the same.
candidates.why_stand: As a successful local business person for the past 20 years, I have been seeing the growth within our district, however our hospitals and medical services are not keeping up with the demands on them. I believe in being proactive, rather than reactive.
